Bug.Summery: need ability to associate a topic with a primary toc
Bug.WithStack:
Right now, if you click on something on the bookshelf, the navigation frame switches to its TOC, but the content frame is blank. This is a good spot for products to put some sort of branding splash, or better yet a description of what's in the book, tips for using their documentation (e.g., how the TOC is organized, etc), links to critical introductory topics, etc.
This is functionality we did have in V1, and we used it a lot. When the user selected a new infoset, they got info on how the nav trees were organized, etc.
Suggestion: In plugin.xml, for tocs that have been designated as primary=true, allow an href="xxxx.htm" attribute, as shown:
<extension point="org.eclipse.help.toc"> <toc file="toc.xml" primary="true" href="intro.htm" /> </extension>
This means there's no change to the toc DTD, and it closely associates the topic with the primary-ness of the toc.
If this primary toc were to be pulled into another toc, so that it no longer appears on the bookshelf, the intro.htm would no longer be seen -- this is fine. This sounds like a good idea. Hopefully we will have a chance to do it in 2.0 The next nightly build (20020417) should support the function you want, in a slightly different manner:
In a toc.xml file, you can set a "topic" attribute on a <toc> and the value is the url of description topic of the toc.
<toc label="PDE Guide" topic="overview/toc.html"> <topic label="Tasks" href="tasks/intro.html"/> .... </toc>
Please give it a try and add a comment here if works as you expect. marking as fixed.
It works as expected. Thanks. One question: Why not call the attribute "href" instead of "topic"; that would be more consistent with the other elements in toc files? We consider the href of a TOC to be the actual toc.xml file, so using an href attribute would confuse matters. On the other hand, for someone who's only contributing docs and does not call help API's (we expose IToc, ITopic, etc), using the href attribute makes more sense.
I would like to revisit the choice of attribute (topic vs. href), so consider the feature implemented, but it's DTD not stable until M6 (when the feature is targeted).

If I define my plugin name to be something like %Plugin.name so that the real name is seperated for translation, when I look at the manifest with the editors i see the string %Plugin.name. This is not such a big deal for plugin names but it happens for every string I seperate which make some of the pages pretty hard to use.
It would be really nice if the pde externilized the strings for you since it should always be done anyway. Notice how 'Plug-in Name' field shows properties entry with a'%' but the title shows the translated name loaded from the properties.

The title is shown resolved correctly. I was commenting on the fact that the 'Plug-in Name' field contained the '%'. I actually hadn't noticed that other, not mispelled, items were being resolved correctly. I was really hoping that the text in the 'Plug-in Name' field WOULD be resolved, and the properties file would change if I changed the field. That would be way too much magic :-).
I think that NL issues should be handled consistently for the entire SDK. JDT has a string externalization tool for Java code, so we should try to be consistent.
For now, I would stick with the current mix of explicit entry (with %) in editable fields and translated names wherever that property appears in the UI. Bug.Summery: PDE should by default override plugins in the target environment with those in the workspace
Bug.WithStack:
If you have a plugin in your workspace that also exists in the external environment, then by default the PDE should enable the one in your workspace and disable the external one when launching a runtime workbench. Currently the user must manually disable the external plugin.
Not doing this by default may cause the user to see NoClassDefFoundExceptions or similar cryptic errors during launching since they may be running against stale code in the external environment. There is already a model synchronizer in place that should maintain single-plug- in visibility depending on the state of the workspace. However, it has been added recently and is still fragile. There are still a number of scenarios that 'full' it, resulting in 'twin' plug-ins being simultaneously visible. Fixed now. Masked external plug-ins (those that have workspace 'twins') are not enabled in the launcher.

If they are just regular links, then you should stick with Tab since that is standard for a web browser. As long as there is some way of accessing them, we're OK for accessibility. For usability, though, it should match the user's expectations. That is, if they think it's a web browser, it should work like a web browser. If it looks like a regular app, it should work like a regular app. The problem with Help using an embedded web browser is that it may be unclear to the user whether it's a web browser or a regular app.
Help can be used in other non-eclipse scenarios (standalone and infoceter/server-based), so in some cases it is clear this is a browser app.
The next build will have support for associating a default topic to a book (i.e. a TOC). We should also have "welcome" kind of page for the help bookshelf as well.
Perhaps we can use these pages to provide a quick introduction to the help features, accessibility included.

Bug.Summery: IProject.move(IPath, ...) semantics misleading
Bug.WithStack:
Moving a project using IProject.move(IPath, ...) instead of IProject.move(IProjectDescription, ...) discards the existing project description during the move.
Why doesn't IProject.move(IPath, ...) just result in something like: IProjectDescription desc = project.getDescription(); desc.setName(path.lastSegments(1)); project.move(desc, ...);
Is this new behaviour? I had code written using the IPath version that broke after the pre-M4 integration build. For projects, IResource.move(IPath,...) is spec'd (in 1.0 and 2.0) to use a new description with the new project name. However, it was implemented in 1.0 to pick up the old description and change the name (and set location back to default).
We will need to investigate how we want it to work and how to do this without breaking everyone. Changed spec to reflect implementation in 1.0 where we use the source description in the destination.
Change implementation to follow new spec.
Available in builds > 2002-03-20.

Lines.Line: 1. The current behavior causes problems (user confusion, loss of data,
failure to launch)
2. The current behavior is not standard behavior on Linux. Standard behavior
for a Linux app is to store program data in the users home dir.
*** Bug 27902 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
I concur with the users below. The current model only works on single-user systems (like Windows) where everyone typically has their own install of the tool.

Bug.WithStack:
Just like all other Unix apps, Eclipse should default to storing its workspace somewhere in the user's $HOME directory. People who want their workspace somewhere else should have to use the -data switch.
Bug 5927 together with the fact that Eclipse wants to save its workspace in the current working directory makes the install directory the current default position for the workspace. As the install directory will in many cases be write protected, the current default is broken on many systems. *** Bug 20526 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 21249 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Bug 23090 suggests the same thing on Win32 boxes. It suggests the default workspace directory should be in the directory specified by the user's profile. This is hopefully the same as what System.getProperty("user.home") will return. *** Bug 23090 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Too many people depend on the current behaviour. Users are able to specify the location of the workspace with the -data command line argument. How about a compromise that will satisfy new and old users: If there's no data argumnet, check the current directory for a workspace directory. If one exists, use it. Otherwise, check the user's home directory. If a workspace directory exists there, use it. Otherwise, create one in the user's home directory.
This way, nobody's existing eclipse installation will break, but new users won't be subject to the really confusing behavior of pwd-dependent workspaces.
I'd *really* like to see this bug reopened. *** Bug 26226 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I also think this should be reopened. My comments from Bug 26226:
By default, Eclipse puts the workspace in the current working directory. In general, users launch Eclipse from the install directory. This model is dangerous in single-user installs because it means that deleting the Eclipse install will also delete the workspace. This model is wrong in shared installs because the user cannot write to the Eclipse install dir.
This model is confusing to the user in general because most applications don't care about where you launch them from. Users have no expectation that there will be a difference if they launch a program from /home/$USER/foo one day and from /home/$USER/bar the next.
We should put the workspace in a platform-standard location. On Linux, the normal place to put the user's workspace would be in the user's home directory, probably in a folder named ".eclipse". I'm not sure what the norm is for Windows, but I'd speculate that a better place to put the user's workspace would be their home dir. For the sake of argument, why would people launch from the install directory on a multi-user install? I would never cd to /usr/bin to launch any other application on unix. Other apps, such as editors and the java command line tools, work the same as eclipse. You cd to where your data is, then you invoke the tool. If I invoke "emacs foo.txt" or "java A.java", it will look in the pwd for the data. If I type "make" or "ant", it looks in the pwd for the build file.
I think the confusion is over the fact that eclipse stores metadata and user data in the same diectory (the "-data" directory). Typically a unix program will take user data from the pwd, and put metadata (such as user settings, preferences) in the user's home directory. In eclipse they're stored together, so it's a toss-up as to which policy makes the most sense. Michael's suggestion about search in the home directory if a workspace isn't found in the pwd is worth considering. Inspired by John Arthones comment, I opened bug 26756 about storing Eclipse's metadata in ~/.eclipse. The point about Eclipse failing if you launch it from the install directory was just an example of the more general problem which is the fact that Eclipse has an unexpected tie to the current working dir. I can think of no other Linux app that writes files to the current working directory when launched.
I don't think the comparison to Emacs is fair because Emacs is a single file editor that you pass a filename to. The fact that the filename is resolved to the current directory is just standard shell behavior. I think Mail is much closer to Eclipse. Like Eclipse, mail programs contain transient user data and metadata that the user is presented with each time they launch. Like Eclipse, the location of the users mail in the filesystem is implicit by default; You don't specify a file to open when you launch Eclipse or a mail program. Unlike Eclipse, mail programs follow the *nux convention of storing their data in the user's home directory.
For clarify, there are two distinct issues here: 1. The current behavior causes problems (user confusion, loss of data, failure to launch) 2. The current behavior is not standard behavior on Linux. Standard behavior for a Linux app is to store program data in the users home dir. *** Bug 27902 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I concur with the users below. The current model only works on single-user systems (like Windows) where everyone typically has their own install of the tool.
On multi-user systems, the default should be to use the home directory.

Bug.Summery: plugins that require xerces don't specify version
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020319
The plugins in the platform that require xerces should explicitly specify which version of xerces they require. Otherwise, if some third party ships a newer version of xerces with their plugins, the platform plugins will try to use that newer version.
Example:
Core plugins require xerces 1.4.2 Plugin com.xyz requires xerces 2.0.1, so they include that version with their plugins
Now core plugins are using xerces 2.0.1, which may not be compatible with 1.4.2. From Bob Foster:
Thank again for continuing to follow up. I did check the bug report. The problem is apparently deeper than that.
I changed all standard plugin.xmls that referred to xerces to use version="3.2.1" match="exact", and I changed my own to use version="2.0.1" match="exact". In this version, Eclipse runs normally but my plugin fails to load and there is no log message at all!
Just for kicks, I replaced all "3.2.1" with "1.4.2". This produces the log message:
1=============<children>============= 2 org.eclipse.core.runtime 1 Unable to satisfy prerequisite constraint from com.objfac.xmleditor to org.apache.xerces. 1=============</children>=============
Not very illuminating. Don't tell whether Eclipse tried to satisfy the constraint and failed or just threw up its hands. Suspect the latter. This is now invalid because platform core plugins no longer require xerces
